SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which idea is introduced in lines 1 through 6?

A.Choice: Werner is focused on his hobby throughout the year.

B.Choice: Werner believes that cooperation is the key to success.

C.Choice: Werner's seeds are sought after by other growers.

D.Choice: Werner's location has contributed to his success.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read this sentence from lines 16 and 17.
:box:Then he covers them with plastic cups to prevent honeybees from meddling.
The author uses the word “meddling” in line 17 to suggest that honeybees

A.Choice: are sensitive to cooler temperatures

B.Choice: will cause problems in the garden

C.Choice: will leave the garden quickly

D.Choice: are attracted to light sources

A.Choice: lines 27 through 29

B.Choice: lines 30 through 33

C.Choice: lines 34 through 39

D.Choice: lines 40 through 43

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: How do lines 44 through 48 reflect a central idea of the article?

A.Choice: by explaining some of the challenges faced by pumpkin growers

B.Choice: by explaining why pumpkin growers have the time to breed pumpkins

C.Choice: by connecting the efforts of pumpkin growers to the size of giant pumpkins

D.Choice: by showing the recognition that successful pumpkin growers get for their efforts

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which evidence from the article suggests that Werner's hobby is popular?

A.Choice: Giant pumpkins have tripled in size since the 1980s.

B.Choice: Competitions can earn gardeners thousands of dollars.

C.Choice: Experts predict that a one-ton pumpkin will be grown soon.

D.Choice: There are more than 80 competitions held in a particular area.

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: Lines 53 through 66 generate interest in the topic of great pumpkin growing by

A.Choice: providing detailed descriptions of the weigh-offs

B.Choice: describing challenges that growers must overcome

C.Choice: mentioning that people can achieve similar results themselves

D.Choice: suggesting that consumers can benefit from these friendly competitions

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which statement would be most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: Growing giant pumpkins requires a combination of time and skill.

B.Choice: Giant pumpkins grow best in regions that have changing seasons.

C.Choice: Giant pumpkin weigh-offs generally take place in the spring.

D.Choice: Growing giant pumpkins requires a background in science.

SubTopics: Analyze how a drama's or poem's form or structure (e.g., soliloquy, sonnet) contributes to its meaning.
Content: Lines 1 through 8 contribute to the reader's understanding of the story by

A.Choice: allowing the reader to immediately understand Allegra's state of mind

B.Choice: sharing with the reader the frustration Allegra feels before the performance

C.Choice: emphasizing how important it is for Allegra to empty her mind of all thoughts

D.Choice: suggesting that Allegra's surroundings are less important than her feelings

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Why does Allegra think of Alice in Wonderland in lines 20 through 23?

A.Choice: The size of the room makes her feel extremely small.

B.Choice: She is so nervous that she feels as if she might be shrinking.

C.Choice: She feels uncomfortable with the jury behind the line of screens.

D.Choice: The boy before her makes her feel unsure because of his skillful playing.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot).
Content: Based on lines 27 through 31, which statement best explains how the photograph helps Allegra?

A.Choice: It inspires a vision that prepares her for performing the music.

B.Choice: It reminds her that her great-grandmother was a teenage musician like her.

C.Choice: It provides a memory that creates a mood of disappointment.

D.Choice: It prompts her to recall a pleasant time composing music with her great-grandmother.

SubTopics: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word's position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Content: In line 41, the narrator compares the musical notes to “flickerings of flame from the candle” to show that the sounds are

A.Choice: strong and powerful

B.Choice: gentle and delicate

C.Choice: quick and changeable

D.Choice: sad and brief

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.
Content: The author's repetition of Allegra taking “a medium-size breath” in lines 30 through 31, 40, and 49 helps to create a feeling of

A.Choice: agitation before performing

B.Choice: release in finally performing

C.Choice: controlled focus during her performance

D.Choice: patience in persisting through her performance

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.
Content: Read these sentences from lines 62 and 63.
:box:I looked down at the scroll of my violin. It's like a seashell, as if there's such a story inside that you could never find out all of it.
The simile suggests that Allegra

A.Choice: appreciates her violin as full of possibility for the music she creates with it

B.Choice: wishes she could unleash the secrets her violin hides from her

C.Choice: relies on her violin for inspiration during performances

D.Choice: respects her violin's beauty and craftsmanship

A.Choice: Possessions can awaken pleasant memories.

B.Choice: Focus and determination are essential for success.

C.Choice: Imagination can inspire the emotion behind music.

D.Choice: Family bonds require regular effort to remain strong.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which evidence from the article suggests that plastic-bag bans are effective?

A.Choice: A city in Texas has eliminated thousands of bags per day.

B.Choice: Officials in Seattle have passed a ban on bags.

C.Choice: Many cities now ban the use of plastic bags.

D.Choice: Many people reuse their plastic bags.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.

A.Choice: information about plastic-bag bans in Europe and Asia

B.Choice: arguments from environmentalists and businesses on plastic-bag bans

C.Choice: data from scientists concerned with plastic bags in the environment

D.Choice: quotes from people living in American cities where plastic bags are banned

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas

A.Choice: The petroleum industry is fighting plastic-bottle bans.

B.Choice: A statewide ban on plastic bags is unlikely to happen.

C.Choice: Paying a fee on plastic bags is unappealing to some people.

D.Choice: Many Americans prefer paper or reusable bags to plastic bags.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze how two or more authors writing about the same topic shape their presentations of key information by emphasizing different evidence or advancing different interpretations of facts.
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Both Lewis Latimer and John Deere were determined to succeed. How were their paths to success similar? How were their paths to success different? Use details from both articles to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• explain how their paths to success were similar
• explain how their paths to success were different
• use details from both articles to support your response
